Award.AwardTitle: Highly Efficient Laser Cryo-coolers Based on Adiabatic Bandgap Shift in Type-II Heterojunctions

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: the objective of this effort is to study and demonstrate adiabatic bandgap shift in type-II quantum wells, and use this process to cool a heat load to below 10 degrees Kelvin.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research provides an excellent testbed to study many important adiabatic and diabatic quantum processes such as Quantum Refrigeration, Quantum Heat Pumps, and Quantum Amplifiers. It also helps advancing research in
many related devices, such as quantum sensors and computers. Using type-II quantum wells, this research advances the deep physics involved in Type-II heterojunctions, including their non-linear electrooptic effects, carrier lifetime, and built-in electric field.

Broader Impact: Small, non-mechanical cryogenic coolers resulted from this program can revolutionize the way we live, since they lead to practical access to our most sensitive optical sensor (superconductor single photon detector), magnetic sensors (SQUID), the most accurate voltage standard (Josephson Junction) and time standards (Superconductor Oscillators) to name a few. Simulation tools that will be developed in this research effort will become publicly available and shared with the scientific community through World Wide Web. Also, some of the results of this research will be incorporated in a solid-state course and an advanced course on modulators. Undergraduate and graduate students from under-represented and minority groups will be encouraged to take part in this research through Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professorate program at Northwestern University. We will also collaborate with a major company to validate the results, solicit feedback, and produce a commercialization path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Towards Laser Cooling of Semiconductors by Anti-Stokes light emission

Laser cooling of solids have been one of the interesting topics from two decades ago. Especially semiconductors as the backbones of electronic devices were under a great attention for this purpose. The advantages include compactness, lack of vibration, localized cooling and integrability. In this regard, Anti-Stokes cooling has been investigated by several groups for optical refrigeration of semiconductors, after its successful implementation for rare-earth doped glass. However, its insufficient quantum efficiency and photon trapping and recycling prevented the researchers to achieve this goal- expect a recent successful demonstration on CdS nanoribbon. In this project, we proposed new ideas to overcome the problem of insufficient quantum efficiency and improve the PL escape efficiency. In the first step an atomically engineered crystalline semiconductor structure was designed and grown. Despite the many challenges in making this artificial material, we were able to grow a high quality sample suitable for the purpose of laser cooling. In order to have comprehensive and accurate results, an ultra-stable and flexible optical microscope was designed and manufactured. This microscope is capable of sending two laser beams at any arbitrary location on the sample while monitoring the surface using an infrared camera. The laser spot size is at its theoretical limit, while the loss of the microscope is at minimum. This setup enables us to spatially inspect the effect of laser radiation on light absorption, emission and the temperature of the material. The next step was to implement the most reliable and accurate method of thermometery.  For this reason we made thermally isolated regions out of the material. As shown in Figure.1, we succeeded in fabrication of isolated waveguides with a high aspect ratio (2 micrometer thickness of the waveguide versus 60 micrometer depth of the valley) by using a novel chemical etching. As a result we obtained a very high thermal isolation that allowed measuring thermal cooling and heating powers as small as ten trillionth of a Watt. In order to also have a map of temperature of the sample’s surface, a thermoreflectance setup was added to the microscope. Noise characterization of the camera showed that within 20 minutes we can measure the temperature with an accuracy of better than 0.05 degree Centigrade, with a resolution of 320×240. As a result we could determine the interaction of laser radiation and the semiconductor structure with a high accuracy. Based on our findings, we believe that efficient cooling of semiconductor is possible. This could revolutionize cooling methods, for example, of microprocessors. Also, it enables very compact cryogenic coolers that allow implementation of superconductor-based logics and sensors in a wide field of applications.
